newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: LG Semicon to sharply raise non-memOry chip sales.
newsitem.headline: LG Semicon to sharply raise non-memOry chip sales.

text.p: LG Semicon Co Ltd, a unit of South Korea's LG Group, said on Monday it plans to raise non-memory chip sales to 30 percent of its total sales by 2005 from 11 percent in 1995.
LG Semicon, one of the nation's top three semiconductor makers, expects its total sales to rise to 30 trillion won by the year 2005 from 2.5 trillion in 1995.
"The world demand for non-memory chips will grow rapidly in the future. So we must focus more on the area," said Moon Chung-hwan, CEO and vice chairman of LG Semicon.

He said international spot prices for the 16 megabit dynamic random access memory chips looked unlikely to recover this year from the current level. The 16 megabit DRAM unit price is now at around $10, compared with $45-$50 a year earlier.
Moon told reporters the company was still committed to its plan to set up a memory chip joint venture in Malaysia with Hitachi Ltd.
The project, originally scheduled to begin in the first half of this year, has been delayed because of prolonged negotiations with the Malaysian government on details.
The venture, which is expected to cost an investment of $1.25 billion, was to process 30,000 eight-inch wafers a month, he said.
